description:
Maybe not the forum for this but ..... Something needs to be done about the cut through traffic that travels down Montview St and the speed that it travel's at . 
All of it to avoid the light cycle at Center and Corey . Maybe something could be done at that traffic light or better yet a stop sign at Montview at Hastings & Kirk and another Richwood at Atwill St would really make it inconvenient for cars cutting through. I know the response is stop signs don't control of slow traffic , however you only need to look closely at the 5 Stop signs on Bellevue St and the lack of cut through traffic from Lagrange St to see that stop signs do indeed work . A little traffic enforcement during the afternoon 3-6 would be great as well . Again in closing the traffic department should at least take a look at this during both the morning and afternoon rush 
Thank you 
Mike Bresinski
21 Montview St

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU)  investigated and determined the following:. MassDOT is replacing the Mass Av Bridge. The bridge is in desperate need of replacement. Before the bridge work takes place certain utility conduits/ mains need to be re-located first. That is the construction you are talking about. Because this is a very fast tracked project we are letting the work take place. We are acknowledging its an inconvenience to the neighborhood. The good news is that instead of a typical bridge replacement job that literally takes years, the MassDOT will come in next year and in 3 days place a pre fab bridge. Its a technology that has obviously greatly lessened the impact to the surrounding neighborhoods. Once again thank you for patience as this most important work takes place. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. After reading the notes about the case, I contacted Feeney Brothers ASAP to determine what happened out there yesterday on River St. Eversource Gas replaced the gas main on this section of River St in anticipation of the City's scheduled  paving in 2016. This will eliminate the very frustrating scenario for everybody of the gas company repairing emergency gas leaks on a newly paved street. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) determined that sections of the temporary trench were not to City standards. We told Feeney to take care of the low areas before December 23rd. Feeney hired a contractor to mill the low areas and then pave. According to the sub contractor the milling machine broke down around 3pm. Obviously this caused major traffic issues and concerns. The subcontractor knew that he had to get the milling machine off the street as soon as possible.  He had it towed between 5-6pm. There were police officers on detail and they had equipment parked in front of the milling machine. He apologized for what happened. They are back out there today trying to complete the job. I called Feeney and told them that they should have contacted me or the CIU  right away on what was transpiring. Going forward in situations like this, they will contact the CIU. I apologize for the impression that you saw as your drove on River St  that the milling machine was just left there willy nilly for the convenience of the contractor and at the expense of the motorist. Obviously after reading my response you know that is not the case. Thank you for understanding. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) Inspector investigated and determined the following:. BWSC was repairing the hydrant at 455 Mass Ave. The sidewalk needed to be closed in order for the work to be done. You have two options when you are closing the sidewalk. 1.  You place a temporary ramps in asphalt against the edgestone and create a temporary path of travel  onto the roadway in front of the work zone. 2.  You place sidewalk closed signs at the nearest ramp at the end of the work zone telling pedestrians that the access to the sidewalk is closed and you need to cross to the other side. Because Boston has narrow streets it can be dangerous to try to have pedestrians go into the roadway. Mass Ave is one of the most traveled arterials in the City.  It is safer for the pedestrians to cross the street, then to walk into Mass Ave. In addition you would be taking a lane of traffic away from a busy street. The good news is the job is completed, and we apologize for the inconvenience. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Department Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) has identified the sidewalk left in asphalt as belonging to Eversource Gas. The sidewalk should have been restored before November 30th. Since the Public Works has a moratorium on all concrete pour work beginning in late November, this sidewalk will not be returned to concrete until the Spring. The location has been entered into the CIU data base that tracks repairs to be made by utility companies or private contractors. If at anytime the asphalt patch becomes unacceptable Eversource Gas will be required to make repairs.  This includes the Winter period if need be. The CIU will monitor the progress of the repair. \Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.
description: Sidewalk has not been replaced yet

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. All over the City utility companies are currently installing new gas mains, water mains electric mains, etc.. In addition many service connections at the request of homeowners or businesses are also being installed. Solid dependable utility service is so important to make the City function. What we take for granted we definitely are affected when a particular utility service is disrupted. We are allowing utilities to work until December 23rd because of the good stretch of weather we are experiencing. Working everyday every available day is critical to make ensure projects are completed by December 23rd. That is why we allowed them to work on Saturdays. The City thanks you for your understanding. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) Inspector states that Eversource Electric is performing a major upgrade of its infrastructure in South Boston.We contacted Eversource on whether the residents were notified of the 24/7 operation needed to complete the project (See Below). If you are not satisfied, please don't hesitate to contact my office at the number below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office. FROM EVERSOURCE. Reliability Improvements in Your Neighborhood. To ensure continued service reliability and address the capacity needs of customers in the area, Eversource is constructing two new transmission lines between our substation located at K Street and East First Street, and a connection point located within the median of Columbia Road near the intersection with G Street. Starting as early as December 1, 2015, Eversource contractors will commence work on H Street between East Fifth and East Seventh Street.  This phase of the project is a 24/7 operation required to pull cable and splice the new transmission lines.  This process is estimated to be two weeks in duration. Parking restrictions will be necessary, and will be clearly posted in advance of activities with dates.   Some temporary modifications to traffic patterns will be necessary during construction.   Police officers will be present during construction to facilitate safe pedestrian and vehicular access. There are no scheduled power interruptions as a result of these operations. Thank you in advance for your cooperation and assistance while Eversource works. to construct this critical infrastructure project. For more information on this project, please call John Hoey, Community Relations Specialist, at 617-541-7634, or email: john.hoey@eversource.com.

At almost any givin time from 5-10 on week nights and all day and night on weekends they leave their car(maroon Acura) double parked on the street.  Along with there own vehicle they routinely have 1 or 2 friends also double parked there.  I have seen them there for so long that the flashers have drained the battery & needed a jump. As of 12/3/15, now that 2 lanes are available again to go from the Harvard Business School over Storrow/Soldiers Field and onto the Anderson Memorial Bridge, the multiple signs along the road that say "Right lane must turn right" are conflicting with the arrows painted on the road that indicate that the right lane may either turn right OR go straight. Someone seeing the signs will get into the left lane to go straight over the bridge, then get stuck behind left-turning cars while the right lane passes them and goes straight over the bridge. Conflicting signs increase the chance of an accident. The signs along the right side of the road that say "Right lane must turn right"  should be covered up or removed (it is better for the left lane to be for left turns and the right lane to have the option to go straight).
